text: A 42-year-old woman presents with progressive weight gain, particularly around the trunk and face. She reports easy bruising, new-onset hypertension, and muscle weakness. On exam, she has a round ‚Äúmoon‚Äù face, supraclavicular fat pads, and purple abdominal striae.
explanation: Cushing‚Äôs disease is a form of Cushing‚Äôs syndrome that results specifically from an ACTH-secreting pituitary adenoma. The pathophysiology involves excess ACTH production, which overstimulates the adrenal cortex to secrete high levels of cortisol. In laboratory findings, patients typically demonstrate elevated cortisol and elevated ACTH. Classic features include central (truncal) obesity, moon facies, and a dorsocervical fat pad (‚Äúbuffalo hump‚Äù), along with purple striae and easy bruising due to protein catabolism and impaired collagen synthesis. This hormone pattern is crucial in distinguishing Cushing‚Äôs disease from other causes of hypercortisolism: adrenal tumors (high cortisol with suppressed ACTH), ectopic ACTH production (very high ACTH and cortisol with abrupt onset and possible hypokalemia), and exogenous glucocorticoid use (high cortisol, suppressed ACTH, adrenal atrophy).

text: Mastoid ecchymosis (Battle‚Äôs sign) is most commonly associated with which type of skull fracture?
explanation:
Explanation:
Battle‚Äôs sign refers to postauricular ecchymosis (bruising over the mastoid process) due to extravasation of blood from a basilar skull fracture involving the temporal bone.

This finding indicates a fracture through the petrous portion of the temporal bone, often accompanied by CSF otorrhea or rhinorrhea, hemotympanum, and cranial nerve deficits (especially CN‚ÄØVII and‚ÄØVIII). Immediate evaluation is warranted due to risk of meningitis and brainstem injury.

text: A 13-year-old boy is evaluated for rapid growth and tall stature far above his peers. He has enlarged hands and feet, excessive sweating, and headaches. Imaging reveals a pituitary mass secreting growth hormone. Which of the following terms best describes his condition?
explanation: Excess growth hormone (GH) produces different syndromes depending on epiphyseal plate status. Gigantism occurs in children and adolescents before epiphyseal closure, causing excessive linear bone growth and extreme tall stature; patients may also show coarse facial features, large hands and feet, and cardiovascular complications. In contrast, acromegaly occurs in adults after epiphyseal closure, leading to soft tissue and appositional bone growth with coarse facial features, prognathism, enlarged hands/feet, organomegaly, and metabolic disturbances. Both are most commonly due to a GH-secreting pituitary adenoma and are evaluated with elevated IGF-1 levels and failure of GH suppression on oral glucose testing.

text: Which of the following best differentiates neoplasia from metaplasia?
option1: Neoplasia is abnormal tissue proliferation; metaplasia is a reversible change of one cell type to another
option2: Neoplasia is always malignant; metaplasia is always benign
option3: Neoplasia involves only epithelial cells; metaplasia involves only connective tissue cells
option4: Neoplasia results in apoptosis; metaplasia prevents apoptosis
explanation: Neoplasia refers to new, uncontrolled, and abnormal growth of cells that is not coordinated with normal tissue architecture. It can be benign or malignant but, by definition, persists even after the stimulus is removed. Metaplasia, on the other hand, is a reversible change in which one differentiated cell type is replaced by another that is better able to withstand stress (e.g., squamous metaplasia in the bronchi of smokers, or Barrett‚Äôs esophagus where squamous ‚Üí columnar epithelium). Importantly, metaplasia itself is not malignant but can predispose to dysplasia and eventually neoplasia if the irritant persists. High-yield review: Neoplasia‚Äîabnormal proliferation, persists without stimulus, may be benign or malignant. Metaplasia‚Äîreversible cell type conversion, adaptive response, may predispose to dysplasia. Clinical correlation: Barrett‚Äôs esophagus = intestinal metaplasia ‚Üí adenocarcinoma risk.

text: Which of the following rare renal cancers originates from the collecting ducts of the kidney?
explanation: Collecting duct carcinoma (also known as Bellini duct carcinoma) is a rare and aggressive renal carcinoma that arises from the epithelial cells of the collecting ducts in the renal medulla. It accounts for less than 1% of renal carcinomas but is clinically significant due to its poor prognosis. Patients often present with hematuria, flank pain, and a palpable mass, similar to other renal carcinomas, but the location in the medulla helps distinguish it. High-yield review: Origin‚Äîcollecting ducts (Bellini ducts). Aggressive clinical course, poor prognosis. Rare (<1% of renal carcinomas). Mnemonic: ‚ÄúDrinking Bellinis makes you pee‚Äù ‚Üí collecting ducts in the kidney medulla.

text: McCune-Albright syndrome is characterized by which of the following triads?
option1: Polyostotic fibrous dysplasia, caf√©-au-lait spots, endocrine hyperfunction
option2: Monostotic fibrous dysplasia, caf√©-au-lait spots, renal failure
option3: Polyostotic fibrous dysplasia, hypopigmented macules, adrenal insufficiency
explanation:
Explanation:
McCune-Albright syndrome is a rare genetic disorder caused by postzygotic activating mutations in the GNAS gene, leading to constitutive activation of GsŒ± protein and overproduction of cAMP in affected tissues.

The classic triad includes:
‚Ä¢ Polyostotic fibrous dysplasia ‚Äî abnormal fibro-osseous tissue replaces normal bone, leading to deformities and fractures.
‚Ä¢ Caf√©-au-lait skin macules ‚Äî irregular (‚Äúcoast of Maine‚Äù) borders.
‚Ä¢ Endocrine hyperfunction ‚Äî most commonly precocious puberty, but can also include hyperthyroidism, Cushing‚Äôs, or acromegaly.

This mosaic distribution explains why disease severity varies based on when the mutation occurred during embryogenesis.

text: Pheochromocytoma is a tumor arising from which of the following cell types?
option2: Chromaffin cells of the adrenal medulla
option3: Parafollicular C cells of the thyroid
explanation: Pheochromocytoma is a neuroendocrine tumor of the adrenal medulla that arises from chromaffin cells, which normally secrete catecholamines (epinephrine, norepinephrine). Excess hormone release leads to episodic hypertension, headaches, palpitations, and sweating‚Äîclassically described as spells. It is sometimes called the ‚Äú10% tumor‚Äù (10% extra-adrenal, 10% bilateral, 10% malignant, etc.), though this is being revised with newer genetics. Pheochromocytoma is associated with multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2 (MEN2), von Hippel‚ÄìLindau disease, and neurofibromatosis type 1. High-yield review: Cell of origin‚Äîchromaffin cells (neural crest derived). Hormones‚Äîepinephrine/norepinephrine ‚Üí secondary hypertension. Clinical triad: headache, palpitations, diaphoresis. Associations: NF1, MEN2A/2B, VHL disease. Mnemonic: ‚ÄúPheo = pressure spikes from catecholamines.‚Äù

text: Peutz‚ÄìJeghers syndrome is characterized by which of the following findings?
option1: Hamartomatous polyps in the colon and melanotic macules on lips
option2: Adenomatous polyps of colon with APC mutation
option3: Sessile serrated adenomas with KRAS mutation
option4: Multiple juvenile polyps with increased risk of adenocarcinoma
explanation: Peutz‚ÄìJeghers syndrome is an autosomal dominant disorder characterized by multiple hamartomatous polyps in the gastrointestinal tract, especially the small intestine and colon, along with mucocutaneous hyperpigmentation (melanotic macules) on the lips, buccal mucosa, and digits. While the polyps are benign hamartomas, patients have an increased lifetime risk of both GI and extra-GI malignancies, including pancreatic, breast, ovarian, and uterine cancers. High-yield review: Genetics‚Äîautosomal dominant, STK11 mutation. Findings‚ÄîGI polyps + mucocutaneous pigmentation. Cancer risk‚ÄîGI, pancreas, breast, ovary, uterus.

text: Esophageal varices most commonly arise as a complication of which underlying condition?
explanation: Esophageal varices are dilated submucosal veins in the lower esophagus that form due to portal hypertension, most often from cirrhosis of the liver. Fibrosis and nodular regeneration in cirrhosis increase resistance to portal venous flow, diverting blood through collateral pathways including the left gastric vein into esophageal veins. These fragile varices may rupture, leading to massive hematemesis and hypovolemic shock. Mortality is high with first bleeding episodes. High-yield review: Cause‚Äîportal hypertension (cirrhosis). Clinical‚Äîhematemesis, shock. Pathology‚Äîdilated distal esophageal submucosal veins. Management‚Äîband ligation, octreotide, TIPS shunt.

text: A 65-year-old man with a history of chronic sun exposure develops a slowly enlarging brown patch on the side of his nose. Biopsy is most consistent with:
explanation: Lentigo maligna is a melanoma in situ that develops on chronically sun-damaged skin, especially of the head and neck in older adults. It appears as a slowly enlarging, asymmetric brown or black patch with irregular borders. Histologically, there is atypical melanocyte proliferation along the basal layer. Without treatment, it may progress to invasive melanoma. High-yield review: Type‚Äîmelanoma in situ. Location‚Äîsun-exposed skin (face, nose, cheeks). Demographic‚Äîelderly, fair-skinned. Appearance‚Äîirregular pigmented patch. Risk‚Äîprogression to invasive melanoma if untreated.

text: A 60-year-old dental assistant presents with progressive hand tremors that worsen at rest, difficulty initiating movement, and a stooped posture. Which of the following brain structures is most affected in this condition?
explanation: Parkinson‚Äôs disease is a neurodegenerative disorder of the basal ganglia caused by degeneration of dopaminergic neurons in the substantia nigra pars compacta. This results in depletion of dopamine in the striatum (caudate and putamen), impairing both the direct and indirect motor pathways. Patients present with the classic TRAP features: Tremor at rest, Rigidity (cogwheel), Akinesia/bradykinesia, and Postural instability. Histology shows Lewy bodies composed of alpha-synuclein. High-yield review: Pathology‚Äîloss of dopaminergic neurons in substantia nigra pars compacta. Clinical‚ÄîTRAP signs, masked facies, shuffling gait. Treatment‚Äîlevodopa/carbidopa, dopamine agonists, MAO-B inhibitors.

text: Which viral component is most commonly used to generate protective vaccines?
explanation: Vaccines are designed to elicit an immune response against viral surface antigens. The most effective targets are viral glycoproteins such as influenza hemagglutinin (HA) and neuraminidase (NA), or SARS-CoV-2 spike protein. These proteins are highly antigenic and accessible to neutralizing antibodies. Option 1 (RNA genome) is not exposed to the immune system. Option 2 (capsid proteins) can be antigenic but are not the primary target of most modern vaccines. Option 4 (polymerase enzymes) are internal proteins, poorly immunogenic. High-yield review: Viral glycoproteins are the major vaccine targets: influenza HA/NA, HBV surface antigen, SARS-CoV-2 spike.

text: Which lymph node is primarily responsible for draining carcinoma of the lateral border of the tongue?
explanation:
Explanation:
The jugulodigastric node (also known as the tonsillar node) is the principal node draining the lateral border of the tongue, tonsillar region, and posterior oral cavity.

It is located below the posterior belly of the digastric muscle and the angle of the mandible. Involvement of this node is clinically significant in cases of squamous cell carcinoma of the lateral tongue and oropharynx.

text: Which of the following best describes the mechanism of action of Azidothymidine (AZT) in HIV treatment?
option1: Inhibits viral protease, blocking viral maturation
option2: Inhibits reverse transcriptase, preventing viral DNA synthesis
option3: Blocks viral integrase, preventing DNA integration into host genome
option4: Inhibits cell wall synthesis by blocking peptidoglycan cross-linking
explanation: AZT (zidovudine) is a nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NRTI). It is a thymidine analog that incorporates into viral DNA and terminates chain elongation, preventing HIV reverse transcriptase from completing DNA synthesis. Option 1 (protease inhibitors) includes drugs like indinavir or ritonavir. Option 3 (integrase inhibitors) includes raltegravir. Option 4 (cell wall synthesis inhibitors) applies to antibiotics, not antivirals. High-yield review: AZT = thymidine analog, NRTI, inhibits reverse transcriptase. Key in HAART. Do not confuse with azithromycin (macrolide antibiotic).

text: A 45-year-old woman presents with chronic dry mouth and gritty sensation in her eyes. She also has swelling of the parotid glands. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: Sj√∂gren‚Äôs syndrome is a systemic autoimmune disease characterized by lymphocytic infiltration and destruction of salivary and lacrimal glands, producing xerostomia (dry mouth) and keratoconjunctivitis sicca (dry eyes). Middle-aged women are most affected, and it is often associated with autoimmune diseases like rheumatoid arthritis. Clinical signs include difficulty swallowing dry food, cervical caries, and parotid gland enlargement. Hypothyroidism can also cause dry mouth but not eye symptoms, rheumatoid arthritis is comorbid but not causal, and sarcoidosis usually involves lungs and systemic granulomas rather than sicca syndrome. High-yield review: autoimmune destruction of salivary and lacrimal glands, anti-SSA/SSB antibodies, associated with RA and SLE, increased risk of non-Hodgkin lymphoma.

text: A 60-year-old patient presents with painful vesicular lesions distributed along a unilateral thoracic dermatome. He reports a history of chickenpox as a child. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: Varicella-zoster virus (VZV), a herpesvirus, causes two distinct syndromes. Primary infection is varicella (chickenpox), a diffuse vesicular rash in children. After resolution, the virus remains latent in dorsal root or cranial nerve ganglia. Reactivation produces herpes zoster (shingles), presenting as painful vesicles limited to one dermatome. Herpes simplex virus causes mucocutaneous lesions but not dermatomal vesicles. Molluscum contagiosum (poxvirus) causes dome-shaped umbilicated papules. Hand-foot-and-mouth disease (coxsackievirus A16) causes oral ulcers and vesicles on hands/feet in children. High-yield: VZV ‚Üí chickenpox (primary), shingles (reactivation), dorsal root ganglia latency, complication = postherpetic neuralgia.

text: Which of the following organisms is responsible for endemic (murine) typhus?
explanation: Endemic (murine) typhus is caused by Rickettsia typhi and is typically transmitted by fleas from rodent reservoirs. Clinical features include fever, headache, myalgias, and a trunk-centered rash that may be mild or absent; disease severity is generally less than epidemic typhus. By contrast, Rickettsia prowazekii causes epidemic typhus via the human body louse and produces a more severe systemic illness in crowded or unsanitary conditions. Coxiella burnetii causes Q fever (inhaled aerosols from livestock, classically no rash). Borrelia burgdorferi is a tick-borne spirochete that causes Lyme disease with erythema migrans and potential neurologic or cardiac involvement. High-yield: Endemic typhus = R. typhi (fleas); Epidemic typhus = R. prowazekii (lice).

text: Which pathogen is the causative agent of Q fever?
explanation: Q fever is caused by Coxiella burnetii, an obligate intracellular bacterium acquired by inhalation of aerosolized particles from infected cattle, sheep, or goats; no arthropod bite is required. The illness ranges from high fever and severe headache to hepatitis or atypical pneumonia, and unlike most rickettsioses, a rash is often absent. Rickettsia rickettsii causes Rocky Mountain spotted fever (tick-borne with centrifugal rash starting at wrists/ankles). Rickettsia typhi causes endemic typhus (flea-borne). Mycoplasma pneumoniae causes atypical 'walking' pneumonia in young adults. High-yield: Q fever = C. burnetii (aerosol from livestock, usually no rash).

text: Which bacterial group is most commonly associated with subacute infective endocarditis?
explanation: Subacute infective endocarditis classically arises on previously damaged or abnormal valves (e.g., rheumatic heart disease, congenital lesions) due to Viridans group streptococci (alpha-hemolytic oral flora such as Streptococcus sanguinis and S. mitis). These organisms adhere to platelet‚Äìfibrin deposits following transient bacteremia, including after dental procedures. Staphylococcus aureus typically causes acute, rapidly destructive endocarditis on normal valves (common in IV drug use). Enterococcus faecalis is a less common cause often associated with genitourinary or gastrointestinal instrumentation. Streptococcus pneumoniae is primarily linked to pneumonia and meningitis rather than endocarditis. High-yield: Subacute = Viridans (damaged valves, indolent); Acute = S. aureus (normal valves, severe).

text: The lesion of primary syphilis is best described as:
explanation: Primary syphilis (Treponema pallidum) presents 2‚Äì3 weeks after exposure with a solitary, firm, indurated, painless ulcer (hard chancre) at the inoculation site and regional, often painless lymphadenopathy; the chancre heals spontaneously in 3‚Äì6 weeks even without therapy. Herpes simplex causes clusters of painful vesicles and ulcers with tender nodes. Haemophilus ducreyi causes chancroid, a soft, painful ulcer with ragged edges and painful inguinal adenopathy. Aphthous ulcers are recurrent, painful oral ulcers unrelated to sexually transmitted infections. High-yield: Primary syphilis = painless hard chancre; Herpes = painful vesicles; Chancroid = soft painful ulcer.

text: The largest component of extracellular fluid (ECF) is:
explanation: Total body water is divided into intracellular fluid (ICF, ~2/3 of total body water) and extracellular fluid (ECF, ~1/3). ECF is further partitioned into interstitial fluid (~75% of ECF), which bathes cells and facilitates exchange, and plasma (~25% of ECF), the circulating component within blood vessels; lymph constitutes a minor fraction. Therefore, interstitial fluid is the largest single component of ECF. High-yield: ICF ‚âà 2/3 TBW; ECF ‚âà 1/3 TBW ‚Üí Interstitial (~75% of ECF) > Plasma (~25% of ECF).

text: Which genetic defect is linked to the X-linked form of amelogenesis imperfecta?
option1: Mutation in collagen type I gene
option3: Deletion in the amelogenin gene (AMELX) spanning intron 2 to the last exon
explanation: The X-linked form of amelogenesis imperfecta arises from pathogenic variants in AMELX, encoding amelogenin, a major enamel matrix protein. A documented lesion involves a deletion extending from intron 2 to the last exon, impairing enamel matrix secretion and mineralization and producing thin, hypoplastic or hypomaturation enamel that fractures easily. Collagen type I mutations are associated with osteogenesis imperfecta and dentinogenesis imperfecta, not enamel defects. Enamelin mutations cause autosomal dominant forms of AI, and DSPP mutations cause dentinogenesis imperfecta. High-yield: X-linked AI = AMELX; autosomal AI = enamelin (ENAM) and others.

text: Aflatoxin, a potent hepatocarcinogen, is produced by:
explanation: Aflatoxins (especially aflatoxin B1) are mycotoxins produced by Aspergillus flavus and Aspergillus parasiticus that contaminate grains, corn, and peanuts in warm, humid climates. Chronic ingestion leads to hepatotoxicity and a markedly increased risk of hepatocellular carcinoma, partly via mutagenic adducts to the p53 tumor suppressor gene (classically at codon 249). Candida albicans causes mucocutaneous candidiasis, Clostridium botulinum produces neurotoxic botulinum toxin, and Staphylococcus aureus produces enterotoxins causing rapid-onset food poisoning. High-yield: Aflatoxin = Aspergillus ‚Üí HCC risk (synergistic with chronic HBV).

text: Which of the following are obligate intracellular pathogens?
explanation: Obligate intracellular organisms must replicate within host cells because they lack sufficient metabolic machinery for independent growth. Classic examples are Chlamydia (energy parasites lacking a complete ATP-generating system) and Rickettsia (require host cytosol). Plasmodium (protozoan) and Coxiella burnetii are also commonly included as obligate intracellular pathogens. Mycoplasma (cell wall‚Äìdeficient), Borrelia and Treponema (spirochetes), and Staphylococcus/E. coli are not obligate intracellular. High-yield: Obligates = Chlamydia, Rickettsia, Plasmodium, Coxiella; Mycobacterium is facultative intracellular.

text: Myasthenia gravis is most commonly associated with which pathological condition of the thymus?
explanation: Myasthenia gravis (MG) is an autoimmune neuromuscular disorder in which antibodies target nicotinic acetylcholine receptors at the postsynaptic neuromuscular junction, impairing synaptic transmission and causing fluctuating muscle weakness. Symptoms include ptosis, diplopia, dysphagia, and generalized fatigue that worsens with exertion and improves with rest. There is a strong association between MG and thymic abnormalities, particularly thymoma (tumor of thymic epithelial cells) and thymic hyperplasia. A thymectomy can induce remission in many patients, especially when a thymoma is present, although remission may not always be permanent. üëâ High-yield review: Cause: Autoantibodies against nicotinic ACh receptors. Symptoms: Weakness worsens with exertion, improves with rest. Associated with: Thymoma, thymic hyperplasia. Treatment: Acetylcholinesterase inhibitors, immunosuppressants, thymectomy if thymoma present.

text: Which of the following best differentiates Histoplasmosis from general mycoses?
option1: Histoplasmosis is a specific systemic fungal infection caused by Histoplasma capsulatum, whereas 'mycoses' refers broadly to fungal diseases.
option2: Histoplasmosis primarily affects the skin, whereas mycoses affect only the lungs.
option3: Histoplasmosis is a bacterial infection, whereas mycoses are viral infections.
option4: Histoplasmosis is limited to immunocompromised patients, whereas mycoses occur only in healthy hosts.
explanation: Mycoses represent the broad category of fungal diseases, which may be superficial (skin, hair, nails), cutaneous (dermatophytoses), subcutaneous (sporotrichosis), opportunistic (mucormycosis in diabetics), or systemic. Inhalation of fungal spores or localized colonization of the skin can initiate persistent infections. Histoplasmosis, by contrast, is one specific type of systemic mycosis caused by Histoplasma capsulatum. Nicknamed 'Spelunker‚Äôs Lung' or 'Caver‚Äôs Disease', it is acquired by inhalation of spores from bird or bat droppings in caves or old buildings. The disease primarily affects the lungs, producing granulomatous inflammation that can mimic tuberculosis. In immunocompetent people it is often self-limited, but in immunocompromised patients (especially AIDS) it can disseminate to multiple organs and become life-threatening. High-yield contrasts: Mycoses = broad fungal infections (superficial, cutaneous, subcutaneous, systemic, opportunistic). Histoplasmosis = specific systemic mycosis with pulmonary onset, TB-like granulomas, potential dissemination, worsens in immunocompromised patients.

text: Patients with uncontrolled diabetes mellitus are particularly predisposed to developing mucormycosis due to which of the following mechanisms?
option1: Elevated serum glucose impairs neutrophil chemotaxis and phagocytosis, facilitating fungal invasion.
option2: Excess insulin secretion promotes growth of fungal hyphae in vascular tissues.
option3: Increased bicarbonate buffering neutralizes acidic conditions required for fungal proliferation.
option4: Enhanced T-cell function in hyperglycemia provides a favorable niche for fungal growth.
explanation: Mucormycosis is an aggressive, opportunistic fungal infection caused by organisms of the order Mucorales (commonly Rhizopus species). It is strongly associated with uncontrolled diabetes mellitus, particularly in the setting of diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA). Hyperglycemia and acidosis impair neutrophil chemotaxis and oxidative burst, leading to ineffective clearance of fungal spores. Elevated free iron in acidosis further enhances fungal proliferation. The fungi characteristically invade vascular structures, causing tissue necrosis and black eschar formation in the nasal cavity, sinuses, or palate. Rhinocerebral mucormycosis is the most common presentation in diabetic patients, beginning with sinusitis-like symptoms and potentially progressing to orbital and brain involvement. Early recognition and management are critical, requiring antifungal therapy (amphotericin B), surgical debridement, and strict glycemic control. High-yield points: Risk factor: uncontrolled diabetes, especially DKA. Pathogenesis: impaired neutrophil function + increased free iron. Clinical: rapidly progressive rhinocerebral infection with tissue necrosis. Treatment: amphotericin B + surgical debridement + correction of hyperglycemia.

text: Which of the following is a general characteristic of bacteria?
option2: Prokaryotic, lacking a nuclear membrane and true organelles
option3: Capable of sexual reproduction via meiosis
explanation:
Bacteria are unicellular prokaryotic organisms. Their DNA is in a nucleoid region without a nuclear membrane, and they lack membrane-bound organelles. They contain 70S ribosomes, the target of many antibiotics. Reproduction occurs by binary fission (asexual). Most bacteria have a peptidoglycan cell wall for structural support. Genetic exchange occurs via horizontal transfer (transformation, conjugation, transduction).

High-yield points:
  • Prokaryotic, no nucleus or organelles
  • 70S ribosomes
  • Binary fission only
  • Peptidoglycan wall
Why the other options are incorrect:
  • Eukaryotic cells: fungi, protozoa, humans have nuclei and organelles
  • Meiosis: sexual reproduction in eukaryotes, not bacteria
  • Multicellular: describes animals/plants, not bacteria

text: Which of the following best describes Buerger‚Äôs Disease (Thromboangiitis Obliterans)?
option1: Autoimmune thyroiditis associated with iodine deficiency
option2: Recurring inflammation and thrombosis of small and medium arteries/veins of the extremities, strongly associated with tobacco use
option3: Demyelinating disease of the central nervous system associated with autoimmunity
option4: Vasospastic disorder of coronary arteries related to exertional stress
explanation:
Buerger‚Äôs Disease (Thromboangiitis Obliterans) is a non-atherosclerotic, segmental vasculitis affecting small and medium arteries and veins in the extremities. It is strongly associated with tobacco use. Pathology includes vessel wall inflammation, thrombosis, and eventual ischemia. Clinically: claudication, ischemic rest pain, ulcers, gangrene. May also present with Raynaud‚Äôs phenomenon and superficial thrombophlebitis. Most common in young male smokers. Treatment requires absolute smoking cessation.

High-yield points:
  • Buerger‚Äôs = thromboangiitis obliterans
  • Small/medium extremity vessels
  • Strong tobacco link
  • Clinical: ischemia, ulcers, gangrene
Why the other options are incorrect:
  • Autoimmune thyroiditis: Hashimoto‚Äôs disease, not vasculitis
  • Demyelinating CNS disease: multiple sclerosis
  • Vasospastic coronary disorder: Prinzmetal‚Äôs angina

text: What is the most common cause of chronic renal failure worldwide?
explanation:
The most common cause of chronic kidney disease (CKD) and ESRD is diabetes mellitus, due to diabetic nephropathy. Hyperglycemia damages glomerular capillaries, leading to glomerulosclerosis, proteinuria, and progressive renal failure.

The second most common cause is hypertension, which causes hyaline arteriolosclerosis and ischemic nephropathy. Chronic glomerulonephritis and polycystic kidney disease are recognized but less common causes.

High-yield points:
  • #1 cause of ESRD = Diabetes mellitus
  • #2 cause = Hypertension
  • Pathology: glomerulosclerosis, proteinuria, renal mass loss
  • ESRD requires dialysis or transplantation
Why the other options are incorrect:
  • Hypertension: 2nd most common cause
  • Chronic glomerulonephritis: less common today
  • Polycystic kidney disease: genetic cause, rare

text: Which layer of the lung does not perceive pain when injured?
explanation:
The visceral pleura lacks pain fibers and is innervated by autonomic nerves. Therefore, it does not transmit pain when inflamed or injured.

The parietal pleura is richly innervated by intercostal and phrenic nerves, making it very sensitive to pain. This explains the sharp, localized chest pain seen in pleuritis.

High-yield points:
  • Visceral pleura = no pain sensation
  • Parietal pleura = pain-sensitive
  • Pleuritic chest pain arises from parietal pleura
Why the other options are incorrect:
  • Parietal pleura: innervated, pain sensitive
  • Costal pleura: branch of parietal pleura, innervated by intercostals
  • Diaphragmatic pleura: innervated by phrenic, referred shoulder pain

text: A point mutation in a single gene resulting in substitution of one amino acid for another, as seen in sickle cell disease, is an example of which type of mutation?
explanation:
Sickle cell disease is caused by a missense mutation in the Œ≤-globin gene (HBB). This substitutes glutamic acid with valine at position 6, altering hemoglobin's structure. HbS polymerizes under hypoxia, distorting RBCs into sickle shapes and causing vaso-occlusion and hemolysis.

High-yield points:
  • Missense mutation = amino acid substitution
  • Sickle cell: Glu ‚Üí Val at position 6
  • Results: HbS polymerization, vaso-occlusion
Why the other options are incorrect:
  • Nonsense: introduces premature stop codon
  • Frameshift: insertion/deletion alters reading frame
  • Silent: codon change but same amino acid

text: Turner syndrome is associated with which karyotype?
explanation:
Turner syndrome results from monosomy X (45, XO). Patients are phenotypically female with short stature, streak ovaries (infertility, amenorrhea), webbed neck, shield chest, and increased risk of congenital heart defects (coarctation of the aorta, bicuspid valve).

High-yield points:
  • Karyotype: 45, XO
  • Features: streak ovaries, webbed neck, short stature
  • Cardiac: coarctation, bicuspid valve
Why the other options are incorrect:
  • 47, XXY: Klinefelter syndrome
  • 47, XXX: Triple X, often asymptomatic
  • 46, XY: normal male karyotype

text: Which antibiotic prevents RNA polymerase from binding to DNA, thereby blocking transcription initiation?
explanation:
Rifampin binds the Œ≤-subunit of bacterial RNA polymerase, preventing initiation of transcription. It is crucial in TB therapy (part of RIPE regimen) and prophylaxis for meningococcus and Hib. Adverse effects include hepatotoxicity and orange-red secretions; it is also a potent CYP450 inducer. Resistance occurs via rpoB gene mutation, so multi-drug therapy is essential.

High-yield points:
  • Blocks RNA polymerase initiation
  • Used in TB, Hib, meningococcal prophylaxis
  • Adverse effects: hepatotoxicity, orange fluids, CYP induction
  • Resistance via rpoB mutation
Why the other options are incorrect:
  • Tetracycline: 30S, blocks aminoacyl-tRNA
  • Erythromycin: 50S, blocks translocation
  • Chloramphenicol: 50S, inhibits peptidyl transferase

text: Which of the following is NOT a common systemic manifestation of chronic alcoholism?
option4: Hypoglycemia due to excessive insulin secretion
explanation:
Chronic Alcoholism ‚Äî Systemic Effects

Chronic alcoholism causes widespread systemic damage through the toxic effects of ethanol and acetaldehyde, as well as nutritional deficiencies (particularly thiamine deficiency).

Key effects include:
‚Ä¢ Hepatic: Fatty liver ‚Üí alcoholic hepatitis ‚Üí cirrhosis
‚Ä¢ Neurologic: Wernicke‚ÄìKorsakoff syndrome (thiamine deficiency: confusion, ataxia, ophthalmoplegia, memory loss)
‚Ä¢ Peripheral nerves: Peripheral neuropathy
‚Ä¢ Cardiac: Alcoholic cardiomyopathy, hypertension
‚Ä¢ Pancreas: Chronic pancreatitis ‚Üí diabetes
‚Ä¢ Hematologic: Megaloblastic anemia (folate deficiency)
‚Ä¢ Oral findings: Glossitis, angular cheilitis, ‚Üë oral carcinoma risk

Not true: Hypoglycemia from excessive insulin secretion ‚Äî alcohol impairs gluconeogenesis but does not cause hyperinsulinemia.

text: Which karyotype is associated with Klinefelter syndrome?
explanation:
Klinefelter syndrome (47, XXY) results from meiotic nondisjunction or mosaicism. Patients are phenotypic males with tall stature, small firm testes, infertility, and gynecomastia. Hormonal profile: ‚Üì testosterone, ‚Üë FSH/LH, ‚Üë estrogen. Learning difficulties may occur. There is an increased risk of breast cancer and autoimmune disease. Management includes testosterone replacement and fertility counseling.

High-yield points:
  • Karyotype = 47, XXY
  • Clinical: small testes, infertility, gynecomastia, tall stature
  • Hormones: ‚Üì testosterone, ‚Üë LH/FSH
  • Risks: breast cancer, autoimmunity
Why the other options are incorrect:
  • 45, XO: Turner syndrome
  • 47, XXX: triple X, often asymptomatic
  • 46, XY: normal male

text: Which of the following diseases is primarily transmitted by fleas?
explanation:
The bubonic plague, caused by Yersinia pestis, is transmitted by rat fleas (Xenopsylla cheopis). After biting an infected rodent, the flea transmits bacteria into humans, causing painful buboes (lymphadenitis). Untreated, it may progress to septicemic or pneumonic plague. Other vector-disease associations: epidemic typhus (body lice), malaria (Anopheles mosquito), leishmaniasis (sandfly).

High-yield points:
  • Plague (*Y. pestis*) = fleas
  • Reservoirs: rodents
  • Clinical: buboes, high mortality untreated
Why other options are incorrect:
  • Typhus: spread by lice
  • Malaria: spread by mosquitoes
  • Leishmaniasis: spread by sandflies

text: A benign tumor of smooth muscle is called:
explanation:
A leiomyoma is a benign tumor of smooth muscle, most commonly found in the uterus (fibroids). These are estrogen-sensitive and may cause abnormal uterine bleeding, pelvic pain, and infertility. Histologically, they appear as bundles of spindle-shaped smooth muscle cells.
Rhabdomyoma: benign skeletal muscle tumor.
Lipoma: benign adipose tumor.
Fibroma: benign fibrous tissue tumor.

High-yield points:
  • Leiomyoma = smooth muscle
  • Most common site = uterus
  • Estrogen sensitive

text: Which neurotransmitter primarily modulates smooth muscle action potentials in the GI tract?
explanation:
GI smooth muscle activity is paced by interstitial cells of Cajal but modulated by neurotransmitters.
Acetylcholine: depolarizes, increases excitability, enhances contraction.
Norepinephrine: hyperpolarizes, decreases excitability, reduces contraction.
Other transmitters (serotonin, dopamine) play roles, but acetylcholine is the principal excitatory neurotransmitter.

High-yield points:
  • ACh = excitatory, ‚Üë motility
  • NE = inhibitory, ‚Üì motility
  • ENS integrates autonomic input

text: Which virulence factors are characteristic of Neisseria gonorrhoeae and Haemophilus influenzae?
option1: N. gonorrhoeae = IgA protease, Œ≤-lactamase; H. influenzae = capsule
option2: N. gonorrhoeae = capsule; H. influenzae = Œ≤-lactamase
option3: N. gonorrhoeae = spore formation; H. influenzae = pili
explanation:
Neisseria gonorrhoeae: lacks a capsule. Virulence factors include pili (adherence), IgA protease (mucosal invasion), antigenic variation, and Œ≤-lactamase (penicillin resistance).
Haemophilus influenzae type b: virulence from polyribosylribitol phosphate capsule, allowing evasion of phagocytosis. Non-typeable strains lack capsule and cause otitis and bronchitis. Vaccination targets the capsule.

High-yield points:
  • Gonococcus: IgA protease, pili, antigenic variation, Œ≤-lactamase
  • Hib: capsule = meningitis, epiglottitis
  • Vaccine targets capsule

text: Which organism is the most common cause of oral thrush and esophagitis in immunocompromised patients?
explanation:
Candida albicans is the most common cause of oral thrush and esophagitis, particularly in immunocompromised patients (e.g., HIV/AIDS, chemotherapy, organ transplant). It is a normal commensal organism in the GI tract, mouth, and vagina, but overgrowth occurs when host defenses are weakened.

Candida can appear as yeast with pseudohyphae at 20¬∞C and as true hyphae (germ tubes) at 37¬∞C.

High-yield recap: Candida ‚Üí thrush, vaginitis, esophagitis; germ tubes at 37¬∞C.

text: A patient with uncontrolled diabetes in ketoacidosis develops necrotic lesions in the nasal cavity and orbit. Microscopy shows broad, non-septate hyphae branching at right angles. Which fungus is responsible?
explanation:
Mucor and Rhizopus species cause mucormycosis, particularly in patients with diabetic ketoacidosis.

These fungi are characterized by broad, ribbon-like, non-septate hyphae that branch at 90¬∞. They invade blood vessels, leading to ischemia, necrosis, and black eschars in the nasal cavity and orbit, with possible extension into the brain.

Prompt surgical debridement and antifungal therapy (amphotericin B) are required.

High-yield recap: Mucor/Rhizopus ‚Üí diabetic ketoacidosis, broad non-septate hyphae, 90¬∞ branching, vascular invasion, black eschars.

text: What is the most efficient screening test for histoplasmosis in endemic regions?
explanation:
Histoplasma capsulatum is a dimorphic fungus endemic to the Ohio and Mississippi River valleys, commonly found in soil enriched with bird and bat droppings.

Although culture and histopathology can confirm the diagnosis, the Histoplasma urine antigen test is the most sensitive and efficient screening method, particularly in immunocompromised patients. Chest radiographs may mimic tuberculosis but are not specific. India ink stain is used for Cryptococcus, not Histoplasma.

High-yield recap: Histoplasmosis ‚Üí Ohio/Mississippi River valleys, bird/bat droppings, macrophage infection; urine antigen test = best screening tool, associated with SVC syndrome and granulomatous inflamation

text: Which is the most common skin cancer, often presenting as a 'rodent ulcer' on sun-exposed areas?
explanation:
Basal cell carcinoma (BCC) is the most common skin cancer. It presents as a pearly papule with telangiectasias, and in ulcerated lesions, the classic term 'rodent ulcer' is used. BCC is locally invasive but rarely metastasizes. Prolonged UV exposure is the major risk factor.

High-yield recap:
- BCC = most common skin cancer
- Pearly papule ¬± ulcer ('rodent ulcer')
- Locally invasive, rare metastasis

text: A patient presents with a painless genital ulcer (chancre) that heals spontaneously. Which stage of syphilis is this most characteristic of?
explanation:
Primary syphilis is caused by Treponema pallidum and presents as a painless chancre at the site of inoculation (genital, anal, or oral).

The ulcer is indurated with a clean base and heals spontaneously in 3‚Äì6 weeks. At this stage, spirochetes are replicating locally and spreading via lymphatics.

- Secondary syphilis: systemic spread ‚Üí diffuse rash (palms/soles), condyloma lata, lymphadenopathy.
- Latent syphilis: asymptomatic, positive serology only.
- Tertiary syphilis: gummas, neurosyphilis, cardiovascular complications.

High-yield recap: Primary syphilis = painless chancre; heals spontaneously; precedes systemic secondary stage.

text: Multiple myeloma is associated with which abnormal protein findings?
option2: Bence Jones proteins and Russell bodies
explanation:
Multiple myeloma is a plasma cell neoplasm producing monoclonal immunoglobulins. It features Bence Jones proteins (urinary light chains) and Russell bodies (immunoglobulin inclusions in plasma cells). Patients often present with CRAB: hyperCalcemia, Renal failure, Anemia, Bone lesions.

High-yield recap:
- Bence Jones proteins = urine light chains
- Russell bodies = Ig inclusions in plasma cells
- CRAB = classic clinical features

text: Nutmeg liver' is most associated with which condition?
explanation:
Nutmeg liver is due to chronic passive congestion of the liver, classically from right-sided heart failure. Blood backs up into hepatic veins ‚Üí centrilobular congestion and necrosis ‚Üí speckled appearance. Long-term cases progress to cardiac cirrhosis.

High-yield recap:
- Etiology = right-sided CHF
- Congestion around central veins
- Severe ‚Üí cardiac cirrhosis

text: ‚ÄúOwl‚Äôs eye‚Äù intranuclear inclusions in pneumocytes are characteristic of which virus?
explanation:
Cytomegalovirus (CMV) produces distinctive 'owl‚Äôs eye' intranuclear inclusions in infected cells. CMV pneumonia is especially important in immunocompromised patients (HIV, transplant). Diagnosis can be made with biopsy or PCR.

High-yield recap:
- CMV = owl‚Äôs eye inclusions
- Pneumonia in immunocompromised
- Confirm by biopsy or PCR

text: Negri bodies are pathognomonic inclusions seen in which viral infection?
explanation:
Negri bodies are cytoplasmic inclusions found in neurons (Purkinje cells, hippocampus) of patients with rabies. Rabies presents with hydrophobia, encephalitis, and is almost uniformly fatal once symptomatic.

High-yield recap:
- Negri bodies = rabies
- Found in Purkinje & hippocampal neurons
- Symptomatic disease = almost always fatal

text: Elevated prostate-specific antigen (PSA) and acid phosphatase are markers for which malignancy?
explanation:
Prostate cancer is monitored with PSA, though PSA can be elevated in BPH and prostatitis. Prostatic acid phosphatase (PAP/PAcP) historically indicated advanced disease, particularly with bone metastases. PSAP is still used in pathology immunostaining.

High-yield recap:
- PSA = screening/monitoring marker
- Acid phosphatase = advanced disease marker
- Metastasis commonly to bone

text: Which of the following best distinguishes a compound odontoma from a complex odontoma?
option1: Compound odontomas contain disorganized dental tissues without tooth-like structures, while complex odontomas contain multiple small tooth-like structures.
option2: Compound odontomas contain multiple small tooth-like structures, while complex odontomas contain disorganized dental tissues without distinct tooth forms.
option3: Compound odontomas arise in the posterior mandible, while complex odontomas arise in the anterior maxilla.
option4: Compound odontomas are composed primarily of dentin, while complex odontomas are composed primarily of enamel.
explanation:
Odontomas ‚Äî Developmental Hamartomas

Odontomas are developmental anomalies (hamartomas) made of enamel, dentin, cementum, and pulp.

Compound odontomas form multiple miniature tooth-like structures (denticles) with normal histologic arrangement and are usually found in the anterior maxilla.

Complex odontomas form a disorganized calcified mass of dental tissues without structural resemblance to a tooth and usually occur in the posterior mandible.

High-Yield Summary:
- Compound ‚Üí multiple tooth-like structures; anterior maxilla.
- Complex ‚Üí disorganized mass; posterior mandible.
- Both benign; treated with simple excision.

text: Kaposi sarcoma is associated with which of the following viral infections?
explanation:
Kaposi Sarcoma ‚Äî Viral Etiology and Clinical Features

Kaposi sarcoma (KS) is a vascular neoplasm caused by infection with HHV-8 (Human Herpesvirus-8). It is most common in immunocompromised patients, particularly those with AIDS.

Lesions appear as red-purple macules, plaques, or nodules that may affect skin, oral mucosa (especially the hard palate), or viscera.

Histology: Spindle-shaped endothelial cells forming slit-like vascular channels with extravasated RBCs and hemosiderin.

High-Yield Summary:
- Etiology ‚Üí HHV-8 infection.
- Common sites ‚Üí palate, gingiva, skin, GI tract.
- Associated with HIV/AIDS, classic, and iatrogenic forms.
- Managed with HAART and local/systemic therapy.

text: In pemphigus vulgaris, acantholysis occurs at which level of the oral epithelium?
explanation:
Pemphigus Vulgaris ‚Äî Autoimmune Intraepithelial Blistering Disorder

Pemphigus vulgaris (PV) is an autoimmune vesiculobullous disease characterized by IgG autoantibodies against desmoglein-3, a desmosomal cadherin responsible for epithelial cell adhesion.

Loss of cohesion (acantholysis) among keratinocytes leads to intraepithelial blistering at the suprabasal level, leaving basal cells attached to the basement membrane ‚Äî the classic ‚Äútombstone appearance.‚Äù

Clinical: Fragile bullae rupture easily, leaving painful oral erosions (often first sign). Positive Nikolsky sign (epithelial sloughing with pressure).

High-Yield Summary:
- Target: Desmoglein-3 ‚Üí desmosome loss.
- Level: Suprabasal cleft (intraepithelial).
- Histology: ‚ÄúTombstone‚Äù basal cells.
- Clinical: Painful erosions, positive Nikolsky sign.
- Treatment: Corticosteroids and immunosuppressants.

text: Which of the following best differentiates a compound odontoma from a complex odontoma?
option1: Compound odontoma resembles small tooth-like structures, while complex odontoma is a disorganized mass of enamel and dentin.
option2: Compound odontoma is radiolucent, while complex odontoma is radiopaque.
option3: Compound odontoma is malignant, while complex odontoma is benign.
option4: Compound odontoma arises from epithelial tissue, while complex odontoma arises from mesenchymal tissue.
explanation:
Compound odontomas consist of multiple miniature tooth-like structures (denticles), each containing enamel, dentin, and pulp arranged in a normal pattern. Complex odontomas, by contrast, form an amorphous mass of enamel and dentin without recognizable tooth morphology.

Radiographic features:
- Compound: multiple small, radiopaque tooth-like structures (usually anterior maxilla).
- Complex: irregular, dense radiopacity with a thin radiolucent border (often posterior mandible).

High-yield recap:
- Both are hamartomas (not true neoplasms).
- Compound = organized toothlets; Complex = disorganized mass.

text: Kaposi‚Äôs sarcoma is caused by infection with which of the following viruses?
explanation:
Kaposi‚Äôs sarcoma is a vascular neoplasm associated with infection by human herpesvirus‚Äë8 (HHV‚Äë8). It commonly occurs in immunocompromised patients, especially those with AIDS.

Clinical features:
- Red, purple, or brown macules, plaques, or nodules on the palate, gingiva, or skin.
- Histology shows spindle-shaped endothelial cells and slit-like vascular spaces.

High-yield recap:
- HHV‚Äë8 is necessary for development.
- Oral lesions often appear on the hard palate or gingiva.
- Common in HIV‚Äëpositive or immunosuppressed individuals.

text: Pemphigus vulgaris involves loss of adhesion between epithelial cells due to autoantibodies against which component?
explanation:
Pemphigus vulgaris is an autoimmune blistering disorder caused by antibodies targeting desmosomal proteins (desmoglein‚Äë3 and desmoglein‚Äë1). This leads to loss of cohesion between keratinocytes‚Äîa process called acantholysis.

Histopathology:
- Intraepithelial (suprabasal) cleft formation.
- ‚ÄúTombstone‚Äù basal cells attached to the basement membrane.
- Positive Nikolsky sign (epidermal sloughing).

Differentiation:
- Bullous pemphigoid: subepithelial separation involving hemidesmosomes.

High-yield recap:
- Pemphigus = intraepithelial, desmosomes.
- Pemphigoid = subepithelial, hemidesmosomes.

text: What is the most common cause of Bell‚Äôs palsy?
option2: Viral reactivation, typically herpes simplex virus type 1 (HSV‚Äë1)
explanation:
Bell‚Äôs palsy is an acute, unilateral lower motor neuron facial paralysis, most commonly caused by reactivation of herpes simplex virus type 1 (HSV‚Äë1) within the geniculate ganglion.

Clinical features:
- Sudden facial droop on one side.
- Inability to close eye or smile symmetrically.
- Altered taste and hyperacusis possible.

Management:
- Prednisone ¬± antiviral (acyclovir).
- Eye protection with artificial tears and taping at night.

High-yield recap:
- HSV‚Äë1 reactivation causes nerve inflammation.
- Most recover fully within 3‚Äì6 months.

text: Which of the following oral lesions has the highest risk of malignant transformation?
explanation:
Erythroplakia is a red, velvety mucosal patch that cannot be identified as another condition clinically or histologically. It carries the highest malignant potential among oral precancerous lesions ‚Äî most cases show moderate to severe epithelial dysplasia or carcinoma in situ upon biopsy.

In contrast: Leukoplakia has variable dysplasia risk, and fibromas are benign reactive growths without malignant potential.

Most common sites for erythroplakia:
- Floor of the mouth
- Ventral and lateral tongue
- Soft palate and tonsillar pillars

These are thinly keratinized and vascular areas prone to malignant change.

High-yield recap:
- Erythroplakia = highest malignant potential.
- Biopsy mandatory.
- Common sites overlap with oral SCC hotspots.

text: Which of the following is NOT a predisposing factor for angular cheilitis?
explanation:
Angular cheilitis (perleche) presents as erythematous fissures and soreness at one or both oral commissures. It is most often an opportunistic Candida albicans infection superimposed on local and systemic predispositions that create a moist, macerated environment.

Predisposing factors:
- Reduced vertical dimension of occlusion (VDO) ‚Üí commissure folding and saliva pooling (common in denture wearers/edentulous).
- Nutritional deficiencies ‚Äî especially B-complex (B2/B6/B12) and iron deficiency anemia ‚Äî impair epithelial integrity and host defense.
- Systemic risks: diabetes mellitus, immunosuppression, xerostomia.

Not a risk: Iron overload does not predispose to angular cheilitis.

High-yield recap: Think VDO loss + saliva pooling + B/iron deficiency ‚Üí Candida overgrowth.

text: Which autoimmune disorder is most commonly associated with secondary Sj√∂gren‚Äôs syndrome?
explanation:
Sj√∂gren‚Äôs syndrome is an autoimmune exocrinopathy targeting salivary and lacrimal glands ‚Üí xerostomia and xerophthalmia (sicca complex).

Primary form occurs alone; secondary form coexists with another autoimmune disease ‚Äî most commonly rheumatoid arthritis (RA) (others: SLE, scleroderma).

Serology: anti‚ÄëSSA (Ro), anti‚ÄëSSB (La); RF and ANA often positive. Oral: rampant cervical caries, parotid enlargement, secondary candidiasis.
Risk: markedly increased likelihood of B‚Äëcell (MALT) lymphoma ‚Äî monitor persistent gland swelling.

High-yield recap: Sicca + SSA/SSB; secondary Sj√∂gren‚Äôs is classically linked to RA.

text: Which systemic condition is most commonly associated with oral thrush (pseudomembranous candidiasis)?
explanation:
Oral thrush (pseudomembranous candidiasis) is an opportunistic infection by Candida albicans presenting as white, curd‚Äëlike plaques that wipe off to reveal erythema/bleeding.

Most common systemic association: Uncontrolled HIV due to CD4+ T‚Äëcell depletion and impaired mucosal immunity (also seen with poorly controlled diabetes, prolonged steroids/antibiotics, xerostomia).

Management: topical nystatin/clotrimazole; systemic fluconazole if extensive; investigate for underlying immunosuppression.

High‚Äëyield recap: Thrush = immunosuppression clue ‚Äî especially HIV.

text: A 45‚Äëyear‚Äëold presents with bleeding, swollen gums, perifollicular petechiae, easy bruising, and poor wound healing. Which vitamin deficiency best explains these findings?
explanation:
Presentation is classic for vitamin C deficiency (scurvy). Vitamin C is required for hydroxylation of proline and lysine in collagen synthesis; deficiency weakens capillaries and connective tissues ‚Üí gingival bleeding, petechiae, ecchymoses, and delayed wound healing.

Oral signs: spongy/bleeding gingiva, periodontal ligament weakness, tooth mobility, secondary infection risk.
At risk: elderly, alcohol use disorder, malabsorption, restrictive diets.

Differentiate: K deficiency ‚Üí coagulation defect (normal collagen); B12 ‚Üí megaloblastic anemia/glossitis; A ‚Üí epithelial metaplasia/night blindness.

High‚Äëyield recap: Vit C ‚Üí collagen hydroxylation ‚Üí deficiency = hemorrhage + poor healing.

text: Which disease is characterized by non‚Äëcaseating granulomas, transmural inflammation, and skip lesions?
explanation:
Crohn‚Äôs disease vs Ulcerative colitis (UC) ‚Äî both are IBD but differ in pattern and depth.

Crohn‚Äôs: can involve the entire GI tract (mouth‚Üíanus), especially terminal ileum/colon; transmural inflammation with skip lesions; complications: strictures, fistulas; histology: non‚Äëcaseating granulomas. Oral: cobblestoning, aphthous‚Äëlike ulcers, cheilitis granulomatosa.

UC: limited to colon/rectum, always starting at the rectum and extending continuously proximally; inflammation confined to mucosa/submucosa; complications: toxic megacolon, higher CRC risk; oral: pyostomatitis vegetans (yellow pustules on erythema).

High‚Äëyield recap: Crohn‚Äôs = skip, transmural, granulomas, anywhere; UC = continuous, mucosal, colon‚Äëonly, bloody diarrhea.

text: A 5‚Äëyear‚Äëold has fever for 5 days, bilateral conjunctival injection, cracked lips with strawberry tongue, cervical lymphadenopathy, and desquamation of the hands/feet. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation:
Kawasaki disease is an acute vasculitis of medium‚Äësized arteries in children <5 years; it is a leading cause of acquired heart disease.

CRASH and burn:
C ‚Äî Conjunctivitis (non‚Äëexudative); R ‚Äî polymorphous Rash; A ‚Äî Adenopathy (cervical); S ‚Äî Strawberry tongue/mucositis; H ‚Äî Hands/feet erythema/edema/desquamation; + fever >5 days.

Complication: Coronary artery aneurysms, myocarditis, arrhythmias.
Treatment: early IVIG + aspirin reduces cardiac risk.

High‚Äëyield recap: Pediatric vasculitis with mucocutaneous signs; think IVIG + ASA to prevent coronary sequelae.

text: Which jaw lesion is typically located below the inferior alveolar nerve (IAN) canal and shows a well-defined lingual cortical depression?
explanation:
Stafne bone defect (static bone cavity; lingual mandibular salivary gland depression) is a developmental pseudocyst representing a depression on the lingual surface of the posterior mandible, usually containing submandibular gland tissue.

Radiographic clues: well-corticated round/ovoid radiolucency classically below the IAN canal, near the angle/body of the mandible; incidental and asymptomatic.
Variants: rare ‚Äúupper‚Äù cases can occur at/above the canal; CBCT/MRI can confirm salivary tissue content.
Management: none‚Äîdiagnosis/observation only.

High-yield recap: Below IAN ‚Ä¢ Lingual cortical depression ‚Ä¢ Salivary gland impression ‚Ä¢ No treatment.

text: Which of the following findings is most characteristic of Paget‚Äôs disease of bone (osteitis deformans)?
option1: Mosaic (jigsaw) pattern of lamellar bone with prominent cement lines
option4: Osteoblastic rimming with Howship lacunae only
explanation:
Paget‚Äôs disease of bone features disordered remodeling: initial osteoclastic resorption followed by exuberant, disorganized osteoblastic deposition, producing enlarged but weak bone.

Histology hallmark: mosaic/jigsaw pattern of lamellar bone with thick cement lines from repeated remodeling cycles.
Radiographic: thickened trabeculae, cortical enlargement, ‚Äúcotton‚Äëwool‚Äù skull; maxilla may enlarge (tight dentures), teeth may show hypercementosis.
Labs: elevated alkaline phosphatase with normal Ca/P.
Complications: nerve compression, osteosarcoma (rare).

High‚Äëyield recap: Mosaic bone ‚Ä¢ Cotton‚Äëwool skull ‚Ä¢ ‚ÜëALP ‚Ä¢ Maxillary enlargement/hypercementosis.

text: Squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) arising in which oral site carries the worst prognosis?
explanation:
Floor of the mouth SCC has the worst prognosis among common oral sites due to thin mucosa, rich lymphatics, and proximity to vital spaces that permit early invasion and nodal spread.

Comparisons: lateral/ventral tongue = high risk with frequent nodal metastasis; buccal mucosa/gingiva = variable (betel quid regions higher); hard palate/dorsum of tongue = thicker keratinized mucosa, generally better outcomes.

High‚Äëyield recap: Worst site ‚Üí floor of mouth; most common site overall ‚Üí lateral/ventral tongue.

text: A radiolucent mandibular lesion with scalloped borders, discovered incidentally in a teenage patient, reveals an empty cavity upon surgical exploration. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation:
Simple bone cyst (SBC), aka traumatic bone cyst, is a non‚Äëepithelial pseudocyst‚Äîan empty or serosanguineous cavity within bone, most often in the mandible of adolescents/young adults.

Radiographic: well‚Äëdefined radiolucency with scalloped margins extending between roots; teeth remain vital without resorption.
Intraoperative: cavity is typically empty or with scant fluid.
Etiology (theory): trauma‚Äëinduced intramedullary hemorrhage that fails to organize, leading to cavity formation.
Treatment: surgical curettage to induce bleeding ‚Üí spontaneous bone fill over months.

High‚Äëyield recap: Teen mandibular radiolucency ‚Ä¢ Scallops between roots ‚Ä¢ Empty cavity ‚Ä¢ Curettage ‚Üí heal.

text: Which of the following histologic findings is not characteristic of oral lichen planus?
option2: Saw-tooth appearance of the rete ridges
explanation:
Oral lichen planus (OLP) is a chronic, immune-mediated mucocutaneous disorder that affects the oral mucosa and results from a T-cell‚Äìmediated response against basal keratinocytes.

Histopathologic features:
- Hyperkeratosis (ortho- or parakeratinized).
- Saw-tooth rete ridges.
- Band-like lymphocytic infiltrate at the epithelial-connective tissue interface.
- Basal cell degeneration (Civatte bodies).
- Wickham‚Äôs striae = clinical manifestation of hyperkeratosis seen as white lace-like lines.

Incorrect option explained: Increased length of rete pegs is not typical of OLP; instead, rete pegs are often shortened or irregular.

High-yield recap:
- Immune-mediated basal cell destruction.
- ‚ÄúSaw-tooth‚Äù rete ridges, hyperkeratosis, and Wickham‚Äôs striae.
- Premalignant potential (especially erosive type).

text: Which of the following features is not associated with McCune-Albright syndrome?
explanation:
McCune-Albright syndrome (MAS) is caused by an activating mutation in the GNAS gene, leading to increased cAMP signaling.

Classic triad:
1. Polyostotic fibrous dysplasia (craniofacial bones, ribs, long bones).
2. Caf√©-au-lait macules (coast of Maine borders).
3. Endocrinopathies such as precocious puberty, hyperthyroidism, Cushing‚Äôs, or acromegaly.

Incorrect option explained: Blue sclera is characteristic of osteogenesis imperfecta, not MAS. OI results from a defect in collagen type I, causing bone fragility, dentinogenesis imperfecta, and blue sclera.

High-yield recap:
- MAS = fibrous dysplasia + caf√©-au-lait + endocrine dysfunction.
- GNAS mutation ‚Üí mosaicism ‚Üí variable phenotype.
- Differentiate from osteogenesis imperfecta (collagen I defect, blue sclera).

text: Which of the following organs is oral squamous cell carcinoma most likely to metastasize to?
explanation:
Oral squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) spreads via lymphatic and hematogenous routes.

Spread pattern:
- Regional: to cervical lymph nodes (submandibular, jugulodigastric).
- Distant: most commonly to the lungs, followed by the liver and bones.

Mechanism: Tumor emboli enter the venous system through the internal jugular and brachiocephalic veins, reaching the pulmonary capillary bed first.

Incorrect options:
- Brain: uncommon for SCC.
- Liver: possible but secondary to lung involvement.
- Adrenal glands: rare and late finding.

High-yield recap:
- Local spread: cervical lymph nodes.
- Most common distant site: lungs.
- Distant metastasis = poor prognosis.

text: A patient reports sweating and flushing over the cheek and ear region while eating. This condition is known as:
explanation:
Frey‚Äôs syndrome (gustatory sweating) results from aberrant regeneration of the auriculotemporal nerve following parotid surgery or trauma.

Mechanism:
- Parasympathetic fibers from CN IX (via the auriculotemporal branch of CN V3) meant for the parotid gland regenerate into nearby sweat glands of the overlying skin.
- During salivation, misdirected fibers activate sweat glands, causing sweating and flushing over the parotid region.

Clinical features:
- Unilateral sweating, warmth, or redness of the cheek while eating.
- Triggered by spicy or sour foods.

Diagnosis: Minor‚Äôs starch‚Äìiodine test.

Treatment: Botulinum toxin injections temporarily block acetylcholine release to sweat glands.

High-yield recap:
- Post-parotidectomy complication.
- Parasympathetic misdirection ‚Üí sweating with eating.
- Managed with botulinum toxin.

text: Which of the following is the primary mode of transmission for the Zika virus?
explanation:
Explanation:
Zika virus is a Flavivirus primarily transmitted through the bite of infected Aedes mosquitoes (Aedes aegypti and Aedes albopictus). Transmission can also occur through sexual contact, blood transfusion, and perinatal routes, but mosquito transmission remains the most common.

Clinical significance: Zika infection during pregnancy can lead to microcephaly and other congenital malformations (Congenital Zika Syndrome).

text: Langerhans cell histiocytosis most closely resembles which hematologic malignancy in its clinical and radiographic presentation?
explanation:
Explanation:
Langerhans cell histiocytosis (LCH) is a clonal proliferation of dendritic (Langerhans) cells that often involves bone, skin, and oral tissues. It may present with ‚Äòpunched-out‚Äô radiolucencies on radiographs, mimicking multiple myeloma.

Histologically, LCH lesions show Birbeck granules (tennis-racket‚Äìshaped cytoplasmic organelles) and express CD1a and S100 markers.

Common oral findings include loosening of teeth and alveolar bone destruction, particularly in children.

text: Which metabolic abnormality is most characteristic of acute ethanol intoxication?
option1: Metabolic acidosis with elevated anion gap due to lactic acid accumulation
explanation:
Acute Alcohol Toxicity ‚Äî Metabolic Effects

During acute intoxication, ethanol is metabolized in the liver by alcohol dehydrogenase ‚Üí acetaldehyde, producing excess NADH.
This high NADH/NAD‚Å∫ ratio disrupts normal metabolism:

‚Ä¢ Lactic acidosis: Pyruvate ‚Üí lactate conversion favored
‚Ä¢ Hypoglycemia: Gluconeogenesis inhibited (oxaloacetate ‚Üí malate)
‚Ä¢ Fatty liver: ‚Üë NADH promotes fatty acid synthesis
‚Ä¢ Ketoacidosis: May occur in chronic alcoholics

Summary: Acute ethanol intoxication ‚Üí lactic acidosis + hypoglycemia + fatty liver due to excess NADH.
